ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Virtual 1-on-1 piano and sight reading quizzes.

Besides the virtual seminar, we also had one-on-one meetings with Professor Lalli  these were weekly, sometimes mandatory sometimes optional, kind of like informal live quizzes. I found these very useful for asking questions, testing my own knowledge, checking if I was on the right track, applying the music theory to playing/ singing, etc.
Weekly individual meetings
The classes were more like live lectures, but there were only a few people in my section, so it felt more like seminar style even though it wasn't necessarily discussion based

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Having zero theory knowledge entering the course, I came out of it with basic musical literacy and an understanding of chords, harmonies, cadences, cite reading, and compositional analysis.
So much knowledge on music, such as the wonderful skill of being able to sing at a desired pitch or recognizing the progression of music.
Basic music theory, everything on the syllabus. Gets a little more complicated towards the end but its super cool to be able to analyse Bach/ Schumann/ Beethoven etc. to a good degree.

I went in knowing nothing about music and I ended the semester knowing a lot more music theory than I would have expected to be able to learn in a single semester. From as simple as pitches to as complicated as score analysis.
I got a really good foundation for the basics of music theory including how to read music, how melodies and beats work, and different types of chords and scales.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I think I would have cemented more of my knowledge had the exams not all been take-home and open-note. Otherwise, the lectures were very informative and clear and I learned a great deal.

The course was very strong overall and the professor's ability to reproduce what was being taught helped with understanding. One comment I have is that the course definitely needs to advertise using a virtual piano (or physical if available) more as this was something I found very helpful.
Such a great intro course that focuses on basics and building blocks to developing a mind for music

The course is excellent. Professor Lalli is kind and funny and brilliant. The pace is great; class participation flows easily and naturally. Homework for each class can get a little heavy/ tedious in terms of worksheets but Professor Lalli was receptive to feedback and made some of these optional. But a lot of people ended up doing all of them anyway because theyre a great way to practice and reinforce the material in preparation for the exams. You also get very regular feedback on your work so thats great.

I think the way Professor Lalli set this class up was great. The small seminar structure allowed him to build the class around us as a class. He is very knowledgeable and skilled at what he does, and he enjoys doing it

Strengths: the class was very well taught and engaging for it being online. Professor Lalli did his best to make the class as participatory and engaging as possible, which I really appreciated. The class is taught in a very easy to understand format. I learned a lot, and now feel like I have a really good understanding of the basics of music theory.

Weaknesses: This is mainly just due to the fact that it's online, but obviously trying to tap along to beats and sometimes sing along to music suffered due to zoom lag.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I cannot think of ways to improve the course's Covid-adjusted practices. Professor Lalli adapted his lectures to Zoom quite well. Even given the circumstances I cannot think of flaws in the course's proceedings. It was difficult at times to sing as a group during class because of Zoom's (probably unsolvable) latency problems.

The virtual meetings with the professor were wonderful, they were both really direct and convenient. They allowed for direct feedback in a course where it may be hard to see every single student in class. Overall was only hurt when group singing or presentation had to be done due to the time delay that caused singing to be slightly off.
This was all managed very well, despite things being a little tricky with doing music virtually
Professor Lalli setup weekly individual meetings that allowed for us to get more individual feedback

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I'd recommend this to another student who has zero theory knowledge. If you have knowledge of theory already, take 210 or another higher level course for the sake of those starting from scratch.

This course is much easier if you have some kind of music background already, but you may be bored if this course is not advanced enough for you. However, if this course is your first time with music it definitely will also be a great introduction.

Yes! Professor Lalli was my instructor and was soooo amazing! He is so knowledgeable and encouraging and spends such a great deal of time to make sure you get the best experience and learn the knowledge!

Yes absolutely! If youre interested in music/ music history/ playing an instrument/ singing. Definitely builds up your sight reading, listening, analytical and even singing skills along the way (only the first three are really evaluated, so dont let the singing bit hold you back). Some people in the class will grasp things a little faster/ slower depending on prior experience with sheet music but Prof Lalli does a great job of keeping everyone engaged and in the loop between class discussion, worksheet feedback, always being available for one-on-onea, etc. ; I suspect everyone was pretty good at the material by the end.
I would definitely recommend! I am not musically gifted in anyway and I felt like I could still keep up in this class! I had to put it a lot of work but it was very rewarding!

Yes. I had a little bit of prior music knowledge, but not very much, and found the class to both be an extremely good refresher for what I already knew, and a great introduction to some of the topics I was less familiar with. Even if I had no previous experience I think I still would have really enjoyed this class. If you're at all interested in music and always wanted to learn about the theory behind it, even if you don't have any experience, I would definitely recommend this course. Prof. Lalli especially makes the course really fun and enjoyable.

extras.title:
MUSI 110 03
        Intro to  Elements of Music
